statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Penny Hardaway scored 23 points to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 97-83 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers on Saturday night, extending their winning streak to four games.
article.headline: Hardaway leads Suns to fourth straight win
article.linkText: Portland fans boo as Suns cruise to victory
article.story:
PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- The Portland Trail Blazers played one of their best halves of the season. They also played one of their worst. Penny Hardaway scored 23 points to lead the Phoenix Suns to a 97-83 victory over Portland, extending their winning streak to four games. Stephon Marbury added 21 points and Tom Gugliotta scored 18 for Phoenix, which is 6-1 in its last seven games and 7-2 in its last nine. Hardaway added nine assists and four steals. Steve Kerr came off the bench scored 16 points for Portland, which scored a season-high 31 points in the first quarter and led 53-42 at halftime. The Blazers struggled in the second half, scoring season-lows of 15 points in both the third and fourth quarters. The 30-point second-half was also a season-low. "The first half was one of our best halves of the year; we played really well and then we kind of forgot to show up in the second half," Kerr said. "It didn't feel like we were ready to go in the second half. We didn't have the necessary effort or the necessary energy in the second half. "We thought we had the game won." Portland scored just seven points in the last 10:02 of the third quarter, and the Suns used a 21-7 run to take a 70-68 lead. "We came out and, I thought, looked a little fatigued," Phoenix coach Scott Skiles said. "We regrouped at halftime and played maybe our best half. We've been playing so well lately, but that was impressive." Phoenix scored 10 straight points in the fourth period to seize control. The Suns shot a season-high 51.9 percent from the field. "They were outplaying us, they were outhustling us and they were being tougher than we were," Hardaway said of the first half. "We just tried to go out and play harder in the second half." The Trail Blazers committed five turnovers in the first half and 15 in the second. "The second half they couldn't do anything," Gugliotta said. "When we create turnovers, we have an opportunity to run and we're very effective." Shawn Marion had 15 points, 14 rebounds and six assists for the Suns. Ruben Patterson, Rasheed Wallace and Bonzi Wells each had 15 points for Portland. Wallace and Dale Davis had 11 rebounds. Davis also scored 12 points. "We just ran out of gas," Portland coach Maurice Cheeks said. "As good as we were in the first half, we were as bad in the second half. "When the tide turned, we didn't run any plays. We had a tendency to stand around." Scottie Pippen, activated from the injured list before the game, did not score in 14 minutes. He was 0-for-5 from the floor with four rebounds, two assists and two turnovers. Wallace scored eight points and grabbed seven rebounds to help Portland to a 31-17 lead after one period. The Suns used a 10-2 run to close within 33-27 in the second. Following a timeout, Kerr hit two 3-pointers in a span of seven seconds, sparking a 19-9 run that gave Portland a 16-point lead, 52-36. Kerr hit three 3-pointers and scored 11 points in the first half. He finished 4-for-4 from beyond the arc and 5-for-8 overall.

Game notes
To make room for Pippen on the roster, guard Erick Barkley was placed on the injured list with left patella tendinitis. ... Portland was 5-2 in the seven games Pippen missed. ... Suns guard Tony Delk missed the game with a deep right thigh bruise. ... Derek Anderson missed his second consecutive game with a right ankle sprain. ... Rapper M.C. Hammer was in attendance and put on a brief dance exhibition during a second quarter timeout.
